comments.commentBody:
I discovered this after reading your post and your interest about the origins of Hestia ...

http://www.theoi.com/Ouranios/Hestia.html

Unfortunately, your chronology is wrong. Any prehistory text will give you the correct dates, and they aren't the ones you're using.

There was no such synchronization 6,000 years ago, no matter how much you may wish (or have been told) there was.

It's just not so. What else can be said?

Because living Africans contain a considerable portion of the diversity of humans, they have received particular attention. Work correlating language and DNA in Africans has been done. This work still needs to be strengthened with DNA from ancient burials.

What I find interesting is that the writers for "Law and Order'' wrote about this issue a decade ago.
Do our politicos do anything, other than steal? Boss Tweed lives on.
Thank goodness for the Times, which regularly uncovers such horrors; a feat  that no other news outlet is willing to take on.

"It also found that missteps by Corizon employees may have contributed to at least two recent inmate deaths." Missteps? Would it be possible for us, who pay for this incompetence, to learn more details. What does "missteps" mean?

But let's consider who else is responsible for this horror: 14 years ago Corizon failed in 30 of 33 quality markers and nothing happened? What would have had to do? Mass death? The incompetence for this spreads very far and wide. Everyone who had responsibility for this horror should be fired and lose their pensions. For starters. But frankly, I expect only speeches and a dog and pony show.

My husband is handicapped and we travel the world constantly. We have medical equipment and supplies that have to be with us at all times.
What works? Look for non-stop flights. Have copies of everything on your person and in every piece of luggage, tickets, reservations, credit cards, medications . Have your doctor write a letter explaining condition(s) and treatments and you are trained and qualified to handle any situation. Have emergency numbers for every company or supplier and if they have a local connection. Notify the airlines, hotels etc in advance and again as you check in. Reserve the last row of seats and leave an empty seat between you. you are playing the odds that that seat will remain empty and you will have a little extra room and less people to bother. On a jumbo jet go for the center row where the seats cut down from 5 across to 4 across..good chance you will have 4 seats. If someone shows up for that seat, ask them to switch with you so they will not be in the middle. Pack a bag with emergency meds and supplies, keep it where you can reach it at all times. I use a back pack with wheels. Put things that go together in small zipper sacks so you do not have to go digging for a missing piece or medication. Plan for something to go wrong, because it will and will be easier to handle if things are going according to plan. Do not be afraid to ask for help...people can be wonderful, including a Polish Dr. who helped us and then had us to her house for dinner.

The most important thing is to start young. Travel teaches incredible skills: working together, patience and dealing with change. Our daughter is a wheelchair user because she has a severe form of Cerebral Palsy. We have now been to 6 continents and have spent over 36 weeks backpacking in Asia, Africa and South America. My advice to all families that want to travel: you can do it. Don't wait! www.NoOrdinaryJourney.com
And virtually NO gluten! Wow, paradise for sure!

My family was part of the original hunter-gatherers. We didn't realize it at the time, but it was pretty much paradise. Yeah, it was a little cold sometimes, but there was a lot of game, and the berries and nuts were delicious, nutritious, and organic. We got plenty of exercise, and many nights, we would sleep under the stars.

Then the farmers arrived with their crazy language and their seeds and they kind of ruined the neighborhood. They just hung around, waiting for things to grow. They drove us nuts, but we got used to them. In fact, I fell in love with the daughter of one of the farming families and, well, I pretty much gave up my nomadic lifestyle (sometimes, I still hunt and gather a bit, but don't tell my wife!).

Then, the sheep herders arrived. Oy. The noise. The smell. The shearing.

I'm packing up my family and moving. I've heard there are some interesting islands off the Western coast of Gaul.

Out of date: STAG!!  I loved it! Catching some waves: EARS!! Had me stumped until I got a couple of crosses. I wasn't sure which DARRIN to fill in, so I just put DARRIN. And at least three from physics NEAP, ERG, PRISM. And by coincidence, I will be teaching next week in OREM!  Fun Fun.

No single article can cover everything. Also, this is a report of a recent paper that took yrs of research and collection of rare ancient human remains happened to be found in Europe and Near East. It focuses on the origin of Europeans.

There are similar research in East Asia and when they publish results, perhaps East Asian news media will cover it. When Sub-Saharan Africans do it, they will report similarly.

It is preposterous and presumptuous to expect scientists with European human remains to have any results on East Asians, for example. When they discovered enough ancient Asian remains, some scientists will do it and publish. Don't bring PC in science.

Agriculture, writing, science came about 6,000 years ago? Where did you come up with this and why didn't you check this assumption?

Agriculture - the Fertile Crescent of Western Asia first saw the domestication of animals between13,000 and 10,000 years ago. There is evidence of cultivation of figs in the Jordan Valley 11,300 years ago. And domestication of plants happened 9,000 years ago in Syria, China, Africa and South America.

Writing - The Dispilio Tablet from Greece and Tărtăria tablets from Romania existed in the 6th millennium BC, thus more than 8,000 years ago.

Science - the earliest example of science is Pythagoras' law which was recorded in the 18th century BC on the Mesopotamian cuneiform tablet Plimpton 322. Thus science - the existence of a systematic enterprise that builds and organizes knowledge in the form of testable explanations and predictions about the universe - did not exist in any form 6,000 years ago.

Thus your belief that there was an explosion of events in agriculture, writing and science that coincides with the Biblical account of creation 6,000 years ago is total nonsense. All of these facts can be easily checked, but you didn't bother to verify any of them. Why not? Why didn't you check your facts before you denigrated others?

I've read some interesting inflation theories that are based on the interest the Fed is paying on reserves. However, sustained inflation requires salaries to rise with prices (the proverbial wage-price spiral). Not likely.

When banks have other alternatives, it's not inflation that will be the result. They will begin to put that money to work. What will happen is the M&A bubble, that is already forming, is really going to inflate.

Don't oversimplify when talking about the indo-european expansion.

Every informed people know that the "tocharians" (now called more aptly the "Arsi-kuci", from the names of the cities they occupied since we don't know their original name) were a "western" indo-european people who, at some point of the expansion (not necessarily in western Europe at the time), went east, cohabited for some time with the proto-greeks (certainly not in Greece at the time), then some time with the proto-Aryans (not necessarily in central Asia), before finding their place in the tarim basin.

Id, implying that "yamnaya" people ARE the sole ancestors of the Indo-Europeans and that their culture IS the foundation of Indo-European spread is a bit of a stretch to me.

Now whether Yamnaya or else, the first Indo-European expansionnists, coming from southern Russia, were semi-nomadic, being also farmers, and new only one cereal : millet.
Seems like more peaceful co-existence reigned among less evolved Homo Sapiens?  Took culture and religion to make us the killers we continue to be.

But who is the criminal, the pharma that invented the drug or the Canadian Government that engages in price fixing? If you really care about who the real villain is spend some time and investigate for yourself instead of just buying into the popular conspiracy theory.

Evolutionary theorist Gregory Cochran blogged back in February:

"The big new paper on European origins is out (by Wolfgang Haak, Iosif Lazaridis, Nick Patterson, David Reich, etc) . ...

"In northern Europe, the newcomers didn’t tax the Neolithic farmers: mostly, they killed them. Razib Khan compares this to the original Mongol plan (kill them, kill them all) before that Khitan bureaucrat explained the joys of taxation. In the Corded Ware/Single Grave/Battleaxe culture, there’s no sign that the farmers are around as serfs: there are almost no buildings, almost no sign of agriculture.

"Archaeologists should read more Conan: Robert E. Howard was way closer to the mark than they were or are. Even good guys like David Anthony were influenced: but I’ll bet he’s over that now."

https://westhunt.wordpress.com/2015/02/11/massive-migration/

The Bible specifically says "Britain and America will go down" and "Germany will rise to lead the EU?"  So the Bible knew about the New World thousands of years before the very Catholic Spaniards ran into it, not knowing it existed?  But weren't they reading the Bible?
AACNY means, until Jeb has accumulated another $100 million in not-yet-for-campaign funds.
We just bought new 20" carry-ons that do fit in the overhead, however, we're fine with gate checking, it's free, and only takes a few minutes more waiting for it to be brought up to the jetway:-)

The size of the bags people are carrying on is only part of the problem - admitedly a big part. Another part is the number of bags people are carrying on.
For me, however, the biggest part has to do with people whose seats are in the back of the plane - and who are often invited to embark first - but who use the overhead storage bins in the front of the plane. People whose
seats are in the front of the cabin - and who embark last only to find the space above their seats full - must now walk to the back of the cabin looking for space for their carry on bag(s). Fast forward to disembarking time. The
cabin scene from the Marx brothers' Night At The Opera should be required viewing for airline personnel and the traveling public in general. It's available on Youtube:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8ZvugebaT6Q.
A selfie of us all taken 80 years ago.
Always be skeptical of a "fairness" argument that just happens to benefit the person making it. I think the big person in the next seat should charge you for helping you reach the bin.
Because lots of folks don't use the overhead.
If the airlines would just enforce current guidelines there would be plenty of space and no need for new guidelines.
All they need to do is enforce the current rules. On every flight I take I see at least 5-10 people put a carry on AND a brief case or large purse overhead instead of putting one under their seat.
